I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of India, on behalf of the government of Karnataka (GOK) requested 
ADB to assist in the area of water resource management, through the provision of a loan for 
investment in the water sector and associated grant funding. 1 This technical assistance (TA) is 
the second step in the process of preparing the possible investment program, following a 
scoping study completed in October 2009. This TA is in line with ADB's current strategy in the 
agriculture and natural resources management sector, that identifies improving water resource 
management  and  capacity  development  as  key  to  improving  agricultural  productivity  and 
ensuring sustainable water use as emphasized in the 11th Five Year Plan. It builds on the 
substantial  effort  expended  on  background  studies  for  agriculture  and  water  resources 
management over the past 2–3 years, including IWRM, and promotes water sector reforms in 
accordance with ADB's Water Policy 2. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  In India, impediments to the supply of water are increasingly seen as a major threat to 
economic  growth.  The  availability  of  water  per  capita  is  rapidly  declining.  Water  stress  is 
increasing with quality deterioration in many river basins. It is estimated that more than 200 
million people now live under water-scarce conditions. Pressure is further mounting with rapidly 
growing demand for water for use in agriculture, cities, and industries. At the same time, 
augmenting  supply  with  new  storage  is  becoming  prohibitively  costly.  Poor  people  are 
disproportionately affected, with less access to water of lower quality. Climate change will 
exacerbate these problems. This crisis is aggravated by inefficient and unsustainable water use. 
Irrigation accounts for 85% of water utilized, 30%–40% of this amount from surface water 
systems. Groundwater is also overexploited for irrigation in semi-arid and arid areas. Domestic 
water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS)  faces  similar  problems,  with  large  amounts  of  water 
unaccounted for. This is attributed to the low quality of distribution services and limited user 
participation  and  financing.  Through  the  2002  national  water  policy,  the  government  is 
promoting state reforms to improve efficiency and sustainability in water use, following the 
principles of IWRM and quality service delivery with user participation. Several states in India 
have adopted the policy framework, but implementation languishes at a very formative stage 
across the country.  
 
3.  Karnataka is one of the most highly water-stressed states in India—leaving aside small 
steep western ridges that experience abundant rains—and its economy is one of the fastest 
growing. Annual utilization of water was estimated at 37.1 billion cubic meters (m3) in 2000 and 
is expected to increase to 52.0 billion m3 by 2025. Meeting this increasing demand is a major 
problem, as surface water is almost fully utilized in the state. Groundwater is overexploited in at 
least 10 of 27 districts. The state thus faces severe challenges in expanding access and 
improving  water-use  efficiency.  Irrigation  accounts  for  94%  of  water  use  in  major  basins, 
watering 25% of the net sown area of 11.7 million hectares. The efficiency of surface water 
systems, at 43% of net irrigated area, is low, with over 40% of the command area deprived of 
access  by  low  service  quality,  efficiency,  and  farmer  participation  in  irrigation  system 
management  and  operation.  Subsidies  for  groundwater-lift  irrigation,  serving  45%  of  net 
irrigated area, encourage overexploitation, drawing down groundwater levels. As for WSS (3% 
of water use), only 84% of the population has access to safe drinking water and only 38% to

sanitation. Only 25% of urban local bodies3  can meet the set requirement of 70–135 liters per 
capita per day, depending on population size; 16% have underground drainage; and 11% have 
elementary sewerage treatment. Most have inadequate supply and low efficiency in distribution. 
In rural areas, while 65% of villages have systems that can supply the requirement of 55 liters 
per capita per day, up to 40% of village systems under perform because of either summer 
groundwater depletion (20%), or insufficient maintenance (20%). Other major challenges in the 
sector  include  increasing  industrial  demand  for  water  and  the  need  for  effective  effluent 
management; forestry and land degradation that affect 40% of total area and cause soil erosion, 
reservoir siltation, and rapid rainwater runoff; and effective sharing of increasingly scarce river 
water with other states. 
 
4.  In 2002 the GOK promulgated its state water policy in line with the national water policy 
and initiated sector reforms and investments towards efficiently and sustainably managing ever 
scarcer resources. In irrigation, participatory irrigation management (PIM) has been introduced 
to improve water-use efficiency and raise farmers’ income, with massive fund provision to 
complete unfinished irrigation schemes. Regarding WSS, the state has enhanced efforts to 
expand access through physical investments and reforms in service delivery including private 
sector participation. Yet irrigation and WSS reform are still at initial stages. Progress has been 
limited to establishing a legal and policy framework for sound management to regulate water 
use. Systems are needed to pursue maximum efficiency in water use and allocation within 
resource endowments, while guiding future development programs with basin-level planning. TA 
is needed to help the state assess needs and effectively implement reforms. The agenda 
includes (i) setting out a holistic roadmap towards improving efficiency and sustainability in 
water use and management following IWRM and sound service delivery principles; (ii) defining 
appropriate  bases  for  setting  up  and  operating  institutions  and  arrangements  for  water 
resources management; (iii) progressively developing a decision support system to manage 
water allocations within basin resource endowments; (iv) undertaking basin planning to develop 
and manage finite water resources optimally; and (v) assessing strategies and programs for 
enhancing water-use efficiency in irrigation and WSS.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The  TA  aims  to  contribute  in  the  longer  term  to  economic  growth,  livelihood 
enhancement, poverty reduction, improved environment, and public health in water-scarce river 
basins through efficient, effective, and sustainable water resources management. The impacts 
will be more sustainable water and environmental management in the state, which will (i) 
enhance access to irrigation, WSS, and water supplies for industrial and other water uses; (ii) 
improve water-use efficiency; and (iii) improve environmental conditions in river basins.     
 
6.  As the TA outcome, the state is expected to define and adopt an appropriate and 
effective system of water resources management that follows IWRM principles that are suitably 
adapted to Indian conditions and can support the efficient and sustainable use of finite water 
resources through allocation, pricing, and other regulatory and promotional means, including 
developing waterworks. Clear and robust institutional arrangements for the state and the river 
basins it occupies and shares will be put in place with the assistance of the proposed loan

services in cities and towns

3
program. Sub-basin level planning will be put into operation following the model framework plan 
prepared under the TA with stakeholder participation to enhance access, improve efficiency in 
water  use  and  allocation,  and  protect  the  environment.  The  state  will  acquire  advanced 
knowledge  of  appropriate  options  for  enhancing  water-use  efficiency  and  ensuring  the 
sustainability of WSS and irrigation, including infrastructure, software system improvement, 
management reform, and economic and other incentives based on international best practices. 
The  capacity  of  counterpart  staff  assigned  to  work  with  the  TA  team  and  on  stakeholder 
awareness will be strengthened in the process. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  IWRM road map, institutional systems, and strategic framework. The TA will provide 
technical, institutional, and other expertise to identify and plan the establishment of effective 
IWRM systems in Karnataka. The TA will support preparing key components of state IWRM 
systems and a work plan for bringing them into operation by:  
 
(i)  developing an initial IWRM road map in light of state policy and plan documents; 
(ii)  assessing requisite functions and effective institutional arrangements for IWRM 
and sectoral coordination;  
(iii)  preparing proposals for appropriate institutions such as a water sector apex body 
for policy and strategic guidance and a regulatory agency to address such issues 
as allocating water, fixing  tariffs, and other regulatory functions for water use for 
irrigation,  WSS,  industry  and  hydropower,  as  well  as  to  ensure  the  quality, 
quantity,  and  timing  of  water  flows  required  for  environmental  functions  and 
maintaining the resilience of aquatic ecosystems that provide goods and services 
to people; and  
(iv)  identifying  appropriate  integrated  strategies  for  water  use  and  environmental 
protection,  identifying  and  quantifying  sector  responsibilities  based  on  the 
outcome of joint sub-basin planning by line departments, a water regulator, and 
the stakeholder committees required for implementing IWRM. 
 
8.  Sub-basin  framework  plans  for  efficient  and  sustainable  water  resources 
management. The TA will support planning in a selected water-scarce sub-basin of the state, 
possibly the Krishna. The sub-basin4 framework plan will be developed to include surface water, 
groundwater, and related agendas such as irrigation, WSS, other water uses, the environment, 
and  watershed  issues.  It  will  set  out  broad  strategies  to  meet  rising  water  demand  and 
environmental  requirements  with  the  finite  resource  endowments  of  the  sub-basin,  which 
include water allocated under tribunal agreements. An institutional setup will be recommended 
that promotes interagency coordination and stakeholder participation and will provide the basis 
for forming a river basin organization to manage water resources and coordinate development 
planning,  should  this  be  deemed  appropriate.  Data  management  systems  and  river  basin 
models will be assessed where they exist as to their utility in providing support to water resource 
planning and management, and recommendations will be made for improving them. A basic 
geographic information system (GIS) will be developed to collate a range of spatial data that can 
be used for IWRM planning in the selected sub-basin and possibly for the state. 
 
9.  Efficient and sustainable development and service delivery for urban water supply

Karnataka and prepare strategies and guidelines for enhancing water-use efficiency and the 
sustainability of urban WSS, as well as for establishing a program for one or more selected 
areas to be determined in consultation with the government agencies. The TA will build on other 
studies and projects to improve delivery efficiency, provide accountability, and ensure cost 
recovery for operation and maintenance, exploring such options as water supply using surface 
water linked with improved reservoir management and such management arrangements as 
public–private partnership (PPP). A long list will be prepared of urban areas with IWRM needs 
appropriate for an ADB-supported program. This will provide the basis for preparing investments 
in urban WSS during the ensuing project preparatory TA. 
 
10.  Performance upgrading of major irrigation schemes. A sound knowledge base will 
be established on appropriate structural and other options for improving water-use efficiency 
through a more integrated approach to command area management in pilot irrigation system(s), 
to be selected in consultation with government agencies that may be replicated elsewhere 
during  the  loan  project.  Institutional  assessments  will  be  made  regarding  appropriate 
management arrangements to attain and sustain efficient irrigation across the full command 
area with progressive productivity improvements. The areas to be investigated will include 
(without limitation) (i) enhanced system operation, including rostering water deliveries to better 
reflect user demands and more effective operation of regulation structures to achieve efficient 
delivery;  (ii)  structural  improvements  to  the  distribution  network  to  increase  water-delivery 
efficiency, such as canal lining and piping; (iii) capacity building for key farmer representatives 
and strengthening existing PIM arrangements; (iv) improved agricultural practices such as the 
use of systems of rice intensification and cultivation of higher-value and/or more water-efficient 
crops; and (v) opportunities for PPP to improve the management of distribution systems with, 
e.g., an autonomous irrigation entity financed by water charges collected from farmers, working 
in collaboration with farmer cooperative societies or other water-users’ organizations.  
 
11.  Through each of the components described above, the TA will strengthen staff capacity 
for IWRM principles and practices, and application in Karnataka sub-basins using the design 
support system and management tools to pursue efficient, sustainable water management. A 
study tour to observe day-to-day operations in an advanced river basin in the region will be 
provided. Stakeholder awareness will be promoted through seminars and media briefings in the 
selected sub-basin, urban area, and irrigation system.  
 
12.  Water  resources  planning  with  IWRM  is  reasonably  well  supported  in  Karnataka. 
However, the TA will require the intensive use of hydrological data and related information, 
access to which is limited as certain data are classified as secret. The timely provision of data 
and their use in the planning process will be essential to the success of the TA. Data-related 
activities will need to be coordinated with other projects, in particular the World Bank-funded 
Hydrology Project 2.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000 equivalent. The government has requested ADB 
to finance $700,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical 
Assistance Special Fund –TASF other sources. The Government will finance the balance of the 
cost, equivalent to $150,000 (see Appendix 2 for details of the cost estimates and financing 
plan).

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Water Resources Department (WRD) of the GOK will be the executing agency, and 
the TA will be implemented through the Water Resources Development Organization (WRDO) 
under the secretary of the WRD. The Urban Development Department will participate in WSS 
aspects, and WRD's irrigation wing will cover irrigation aspects. The WRD secretary will be the 
executive TA director, with day-to-day activities managed by the chief engineer of WRDO as TA 
manager. The GOK will form (i) a TA steering committee chaired by the chief secretary and 
including  the  heads  of  relevant  departments,  with  the  WRD  secretary  serving  as  member 
secretary; (ii) an advisory group of recognized local experts; and (iii) a TA working group 
including representatives of relevant departments headed by the WRD secretary and chief 
secretary.  A  central  advisory  group  may  be  formed  and  chaired  by  the  Central  Water 
Commission.   
 
15.  The TA will be undertaken over 6 months tentatively set for March–August 2010 by a 
team  of  (16)  consultants  engaged  through  an  international  firm  associated  with  national 
consultants. ADB will recruit the consulting firm using quality- and cost-based selection at a ratio 
of 80:20 and simplified technical proposals. The TA will require a total of 48 person-months of 
consultancy, 12 person-months international and 36 person-months national. The team will 
possess expertise in areas including but not limited to water resources management, hydrology, 
hydro-geology, sub-basin planning, GIS, WSS, and irrigation design. The consultancy and any 
procurement  to  be  done  will  occur  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) and ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, 
as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 
3. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook.5. 
 
16.  The India Resident Mission (INRM) will monitor TA implementation in coordination with 
the Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Social Services Division (SANS) through joint review 
missions and regular interaction with the WRD, GOK, and central government bodies. The GOK 
will provide counterpart staff, the necessary hydrological and other data, surveys for additional 
data collection and preparing investment proposals, and basic design under the guidance of the 
TA.  GOK and ADB will monitor progress towards achieving TA outcomes and outputs on the 
basis of the consultants' inception report for work planning and schedules, bi-monthly progress 
briefs, and midterm progress report, addressing progress, issues, and recommendations for 
intended outputs. The GOK will monitor progress and quality through regular steering committee 
meetings, working group meetings and interaction with TA consultants. ADB will monitor and 
review TA progress and interim and draft outputs through inception and review missions, with 
key  missions  such  as  inception,  midterm,  and  draft  final  review.  Support  from  the  Urban 
Development Division will be sought for planning and implementing WSS items.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for Integrated Water Resources Management and Sustainable Water 
Service Delivery in Karnataka, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objectives 
1.  The principal objectives of the technical assistance (TA) for Integrated Water Resources 
Management and Sustainable Water Service Delivery in Karnataka are to 
(i)  help the government of Karnataka (GOK) define and adopt an appropriate and 
effective  system  of  water  resources  management  following  integrated  water 
resources management (IWRM) principles that are suitably adapted to Indian 
conditions  and  can  support  the  efficient  and  sustainable  use  of  finite  water 
resources  through  allocation,  pricing,  and  other  regulatory  and  development 
means, including investments in infrastructure, some of which may be funded 
under an ADB loan; 
(ii)  advance the knowledge of key stakeholders on appropriate options for enhancing 
water-use efficiency and the sustainability of water supply and sanitation (WSS) 
and  irrigation,  including  infrastructure  and  software-system  improvement, 
management reforms, and economic and other incentives based on international 
best practices; 
(iii)  Strengthen institutional arrangements for managing selected urban centers—and 
possibly  periurban  and  proposed  new  centers  for  urban  development—and 
manage one or more selected irrigation schemes, including capacity building for 
key stakeholders in existing participatory irrigation management mechanisms; 
and 
(iv)  build the capacity of counterpart staff assigned to work with the TA team and 
other key stakeholders involved in water management. 
 
B.  Scope of Work  
2.  To reach these objectives, the following activities will be undertaken, grouped into five 
components: 
 
3.  Component 1: IWRM Road map, Institutional Systems, and Strategic Framework. 
This component will provide technical, institutional, and other expertise to identify and plan the 
establishment of effective IWRM systems in Karnataka. The TA will support the preparation of 
some key components of state IWRM systems and of a work plan for bringing them into 
operation. The main activities will be to 
(i)  develop an initial IWRM road map in light of existing policy and plan documents, 
as well as consultations to determine the future needs of the state; 
(ii)  assess requisite functions and effective institutional arrangements for IWRM and 
sectoral coordination; 
(iii)  prepare proposals for a water sector apex body and new regulatory agency; 
(iv)  identify appropriate IWRM strategies for water use and environmental protection; 
and 
(v)  prepare  and  implement  a  capacity-building  action  plan  for  IWRM  for  key 
government stakeholders. 
 
4.  Component 2: Sub-basin Framework Plans for Efficient and Sustainable Water

Resources Management. This component will support planning in a selected water-scarce

sub-basin in the state. The sub-basin framework plan will (i) include surface water, groundwater, 
and related agendas such as irrigation, WSS and other water uses, environmental protection, 
and watershed issues; (ii) provide for enhanced institutional arrangements for improved sub-
basin  management;  and  (iii)  set  out  broad  strategies  to  meet  rising  water  demand  and

12      Appendix 3        
 
environmental requirements within the finite resource endowments of the sub-basin, which 
include water allocated in tribunal agreements. The main activities will be to 
(i)  identify, with the Water Resources Department (WRD), an appropriate pilot sub-
basin for framework planning; 
(ii)  assess data management systems and river basin models where they exist; 
(iii)  develop a basic geographic information system to assemble spatial data for 
planning; 
(iv)  work with stakeholders at the state and sub-basin level to identify a strategic 
vision and objectives for IWRM; 
(v)  identify institutional enhancements and investment projects to achieve the vision 
and objectives; 
(vi)  assess the need for a river basin organization to plan and manage sub-basin 
water resources; 
(vii)  prepare a design and a plan for establishing a river basin organization, if deemed 
appropriate; 
(viii)  prepare and implement a capacity-building action plan for sub-basin decision 
makers and water managers; and 
(ix)  prepare the sub-basin framework plan. 
 
5.  Component 3: Efficient and Sustainable Development Service Delivery for Urban 
WSS. This component will build on other studies and projects to improve delivery efficiency, 
provider  accountability,  and  the  recovery  of  operation  and  maintenance  costs,  exploring 
alternative  intervention  options  such  as  the  supply  of  surface  water  linked  with  improved 
management of reservoirs and such management arrangements as public–private partnership 
(PPP). The main activities will be to 
(i)  assess the current situation with respect to urban WSS in Karnataka, 
(ii)  prepare broad strategies and guidelines for enhancing water-use efficiency and 
the sustainability of urban WSS, 
(iii)  work with government agencies to select one or more urban areas for piloting 
further study to prepare a long list of urban areas with IWRM needs that would be 
appropriate for future ADB support, 
(iv)  identify  a  range  of  policy  enhancements  and  intervention  options  for  more 
effective provision of WSS services, 
(v)  develop a program of physical investments for the agreed pilot areas, 
(vi)  develop strategies and proposals for improved management of WSS schemes 
including PPP options, and  
(vii)  prepare and implement a capacity-building action plan for selected urban WSS 
decision makers and managers. 
 
6.  Component  4:  Performance  Upgrading  of  Major  Irrigation  Schemes.  A  sound 
knowledge base will be established on appropriate structural and other options for improving 
water-use efficiency through a more integrated approach to command area management in a 
pilot irrigation system to be selected in consultation with government agencies that may be 
replicated elsewhere during the loan project. Institutional assessments will be undertaken as to 
the appropriate management arrangements to attain and sustain efficient irrigation across the 
full command area with progressive productivity improvements. The main activities will be to 
(i)  assess current irrigation management and water-use efficiency in Karnataka, 
including institutional arrangements; 
(ii)  work with government agencies to select one or more pilot irrigation areas for 
inclusion in the TA; 
(iii)  develop in the pilot area(s) proposals for enhanced system operation, including 
effective water sharing and rostering and improved regulation;

Appendix 3       13 
 
(iv)  assess the need for structural improvements, such as canal lining and piping, 
and recommend appropriate investments; 
(v)  develop  proposals  for  building  the  capacity  of  farmers  and  strengthening 
participatory irrigation management (PIM) arrangements; 
(vi)  develop  recommendations  for  improved  agricultural  practices  to  increase 
production; 
(vii)  assess the impact of water tariff structures on water-use efficiency; 
(viii)  explore  opportunities  for  PPP  to  improve  the  management  of  distribution 
systems; 
(ix)  prepare and implement a capacity-building plan for key farmer representatives 
and strengthening existing PIM; and 
(x)  prepare  and  implement  a  capacity-building  action  plan  for  selected  irrigation 
scheme decision makers and managers. 
 
7.  Component  5:  Project  Management  and  Coordination.  Apart  from  the  technical 
components  described  above,  the  TA  will  require  effective  project  management  and 
coordination of agencies and other stakeholders. This component will include the following main 
activities: 
(i)  Provide project management, including work scheduling and monitoring. 
(ii)  Facilitate effective liaison with the WRD as the executing agency, other agencies, 
and ADB. 
(iii)  Help to organize workshops, TA steering committee and working and advisory 
group meetings, and ADB missions. 
(iv)  Take a lead role in coordinating key stakeholders in the project. 
(v)  Prepare and submit the inception report. 
(vi)  Prepare and submit the midterm report. 
(vii)  Prepare and submit the final report. 
 
C.  Expertise Requirements 
8.  It is expected that professional staff with qualifications outlined in Table A3 will be 
required to carry out the activities specified above. More detailed terms of reference are in 
Supplementary Appendix 1.
